title: Fix non-interactive SSH commands in task setup
body:
This PR fixes a bug found by @concretevitamin. It adds SSH agent forwarding back to the SSH options list and skips the yes/no check required by GitHub/other hosts the first time a user makes an SSH connection with a host (this can be a problem when a user non-interactively performs an SSH connection, such as through git cloning in run/setup).


### Tested
```
# above.yaml
setup:
  git clone git@github.com:sky-proj/sky.git
```
```
sky launch above.yaml
```
Verified sky exist on machine.

### TODO (not for this PR)
Get SSH forwarding to work for `run:`. This is more difficult due to the fact that we submit jobs with Ray and not via direct SSH where we can control these parameters. Filed in #535

title: Fix aws apt install

Closes #24 and #145, by adding the command suggested by @concretevitamin ([ref](https://docs.ray.io/en/latest/cluster/aws-tips.html#using-amazon-efs)) to the setup of the `aws-ray.yaml.j2` template. These commands do not add much overhead to the provisioning process. 

**Before:**
1. `ray up` takes 184.23 seconds, 
2. `ray up` again (by `sky launch -c`) takes 27.53 seconds. (This should be optimized later as well -- filed an issue #530)

2. `ray up` again (by `sky launch -c`) takes 26.65 seconds.

resources:

setup: |

run: |

title: [Demo][WIP] Storage mounting
body:
This PR serves as a functioning demo for the upcoming storage mounting feature. This MVP has been implemented on AWS/S3 using [goofys](https://github.com/kahing/goofys). 

To try it out:
1. Checkout `storagemounting` branch
2. Edit [examples/storage_mount_demo.yaml](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/compare/storagemounting?expand=1#diff-66dc0deb8c3775e2779da6f5ccf762ccc25a474921c84f7f351a9d888d028401) and specify a custom bucket name (instead of `romil-fs`)
3. Do whatever you'd like in `setup` and `run`.
4. `sky launch storage_mount_demo.yaml`
5. Install goofys on your laptop and view the results locally with `goofys <bucket> <mntpath>`

Also tested working for multinode mounting (`num_nodes: 2`).

Ignore the code quality, ignore the failing tests - this is intended to be a demo PR and will not be merged.

title: Added FileLock on cluster launch and teardown
body:
Solves #455 by adding a lock around cluster launch and teardown.

Test:

1. run `sky cpunode` from one terminal
2. while its running try `sky down sky-cpunode` from another: returns  `Cluster is locked. Check to see if it is still being launched.`
3. terminate `sky cpunode`
4. retry `sky down` and see it succeed

Possibly could hold the lock for less time but since down and crucial, I think it makes sense to hold throughout the entire process.

title: Timeout for multi-node launching
body:
This is to resolve #502. We will timeout the gang scheduling if we fail to launch at least 1 node in 30 seconds when there is any node that should be launched (launch means: provision without any setup). The fail case relates to quota limit or resources availability limit. We can further reduce the `timeout` to simulate the AWS UI behavior as mentioned in #502 (head node still needs to be provisioned first), but it will disable the retry for resources availability.

This also fixes a problem in #413, where `ray exec 'ray status'` fails, by caching the head_ip by ourselves.

PS: I changed the `upscaling_speed` to `num_nodes - 1`, so that ray will try to launch all the worker nodes when the heads are ready (increasing the parallelism), instead of `upscaling_speed * ready_nodes` each time. (Side effect: it will launch as many instances as possible and then teardown them, if the resources is not enough).

Tested (the following cluster `scale-n` indicates cluster with `num_nodes=n`:
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-3 examples/minimal.yaml` (it fails from the first region in 4 min (start from `sky launch`) due to the quota limit, and then successfully launched on the second region in min).
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-1000 examples/minimal.yaml` (it fails all the aws regions in 12 min)
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-18 examples/minimal.yaml` (Daniel's usecase, it takes 10 min (4min of it fails from the first region) to provision the instances)
  ```
  sky launch -c scale-18 --cloud aws examples/minimal.yaml  28.11s user 8.40s system 5% cpu 10:13.99 total
  ```
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-3 --cloud gcp examples/minimal.yaml` 
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-3 --cloud azure examples/minimal.yaml` 
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-1000 --cloud gcp examples/minimal.yaml` (timeout all the region/zones within 1:40:00)
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-1000 --cloud azure examples/minimal.yaml` (timeout all the region/zones within 4:15:00, the mainly reason is that launching and terminating on azure is very slow)
- [x] `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh` (Tested with azure_start_stop disabled)

Note: the time for scale-1000 is still not good especially for azure and gcp, but at least it is better than before, which will hang forever.

Future TODO: check the quota before we call the `ray up` so we can get rid of the long waiting time for the quota limit.

title: Fix Azure resource leak
body:
Unfortunately I cannot reproduce the bug with my laptop. But it looks like the valid fix. @infwinston Could you try this simple fix?

BTW, we are still leaking other resources for all clouds (because of design of Ray autoscaler), e.g., credentials and security configurations. Not sure if there are limits of these resources. The fundamental fix would be deleting the resource group, which turns out incompatible with Ray autoscaler (raise exceptions). Also deleting the resource group is the correct way of cleaning up azure resources.

Closes #426

title: [docker] Change remote working directory into `/sky_workdir`
body:
This PR fixes the name of the remote working directory when using the local docker backend: from `f"/{task.work_dir}"` to `/sky_workdir`.

This PR also fixes #303 , a failure from `--workdir .`. The source of the bug was `shutil.copytree(copy_path, dst=f'{tempdir}/{task.workdir}')`; because `shutil.copytree` requires `dst` not already exist, `dst` must not be `f'{tempdir}/.'`. Thus, this PR fixes `dst` to `f'{tempdir}/sky_workdir'`.

title: Fix `sky logs` with interactive ssh causing job status wrongly set if ctrl-c'ed
body:
This PR fixes the following problem introduced by #454, due to the `-tt` option added to the `ssh` for `sky logs`

1. `sky logs min 1` and then Ctrl-C at the proper time (during the L295 in `job_lib.py` is updating the job status using `ray job status`)
2. The Ctrl-C will be received by the `ray job status`, since `ssh -tt` will pass Ctrl-C to the remote process and kill it.
3. As the `ray job status` is killed, the output does not have the required status of the job, and sky will set the job to `FAILED`, though it is still running.

To fix this problem this PR changes the `sky logs` read-only for the job table. 

A future note: we should make sure all the interactive mode ssh be read-only to the job table.

title: Simple SSH into Multi-node Workers from Local
body:
## PR Details
Resolves #457 and #252. This issue also affected our initial user and affected my debugging iteration speed when working with Multinode setups. Hence, here is a fix to make everyone's lives easier.

Now any user can easily ssh into worker nodes. Suppose there are `3` nodes in the cluster named `hello`.
```
# SSH into head node
ssh hello 
# SSH into Worker 1
ssh hello-worker1
# SSH into Worker 2 
ssh hello-worker2
```

## Tests

`sky launch -c examples/env_check.yaml` with 3 nodes
`~/.ssh/config:`
```
Include /Users/michaelluo/.sky/ssh/hello

# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down-c hello` to remove)
Host hello
  HostName 54.91.127.194
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22
```

`sky down hello`
`~/.ssh/config` is empty and `~/.sky/ssh/hello` is gone


*Note*: SSH to Worker from Head is not done. It is a lot more invovled.

title: Parallel Setup + Filemounting
body:
This PR address #453. This speeds up setup and filemounting via parallel threads.

## Tests
```
resources:
  cloud: aws

num_nodes: 2  

workdir: .

setup: |
  echo "here"
  echo "export TEST_VAR=test" >> ~/.bashrc

file_mounts:
  /sky: ~/Downloads/temp
  ~/tmpfile: ~/tmpfile


run: |
  if [[ -z "${TEST_VAR}" ]]; then
    echo "TEST_VAR is not set"
    exit 1
  else
    echo "TEST_VAR is set to ${TEST_VAR}"
  fi

  if [[ -d ~/sky_workdir/sky ]]; then
    echo "~/sky_workdir/sky exists"
  else
    echo "~/sky_workdir/sky does not exist"
    exit 1
  fi

  echo NODE ID: $SKY_NODE_RANK
  echo NODE IPS: "$SKY_NODE_IPS"
  worker_addr=`echo "$SKY_NODE_IPS" | sed -n 2p`
  echo Worker IP: $worker_addr

```

title: Fix delayed logs of `sky logs` locally vs `tail -f` remotely
body:
Closes #451 

The previous delay can be as large as 5 minutes. I did the following changes to optimize the situation.
1. ~~Using the `ray job logs` instead of our self-implemented busy for loop for tailing the log file. (`ray job` API has a shorter calling path)~~ I have to bring back our own log tailing function, since the `ray job logs` does not handle progress bar correctly.
2. Change the SshMode for log tailing to `Interactive`, so that the `ssh` buffer is disabled.
3. Remove the log redirecting and parsing for the `subprocess` for the log tailing.

The first two modifications reduce the logging delay from 5 min to around 6 seconds. The last modification reduces the logging delay to within 1 second by eyes. After changing back the log tailing function to our own, the time delay is still within 1 second.

Tested:
`sky launch -c test-log examples/resnet_app.yaml` (changed the `train_steps` to 25000)
- [x]  Compare `sky logs test-log 1` vs `ssh test-log; tail -f ./sky_logs/.../run.log`
- [x]  Compare `sky exec test-log "tail -f ./sky_logs/.../run.log"` vs `ssh test-log; tail -f ./sky_logs/.../run.log`

title: Fixing Relative Directory for Workdir and File Mounts (`~/sky_workdir/...` not `~/sky_workdir/workdir/...`)
body: Fixes #442 The original PR #431 addressed symlinks by rsyncing only the symbolic link IF the specified filemount/workdir is a symbolic link. These changes introduced a new bug, which alters with `workdir` and `filemounts` dirs are located relative to mount path. This is due to `rsync ~/Downloads/temp server:/sky` vs `rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` having very different behaviors. Problem 1: Choosing `rsync ~/Downloads/temp server:/sky` results in `~/sky_workdir/workdir/...` which is bad. Problem 2: Choosing `rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` affects symbolic links. if ` ~/Downloads/temp/` is a symlink, `rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` uploads the symlink's target folder contents. This PR achieves a compromise between these two problems. When the workdir/source path is a symlink, it will `rsync ~/Downloads/temp server:/sky` and upload nothing onto the server (except for symlink). Otherwise (not a symlink normal dir), it will ``rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` ## Tests - [x] Passes `examples/using_file_mounts.yaml` - [x] Passes `examples/resnet_app_storage.yaml` (Tests the relative placement of workdir and file mounts such as all the TF record files in `/tmp/imagenet/...` for training)

title: Remove tracebacks for exceptions to improve UX
body:
Previously, the raised exceptions will print a large amount of unnecessary traceback information of the internal sky code as well `ssh` error, so that the user's file_mounts / setup / run error will be more close to the end and easier to find. This PR suppresses the errors that occurred in the following yaml. Closes #384 .
```yaml
# workdir: ~/not-exits

# file_mounts:
#  /not-exists: ./examples
#  ~/test: ~/not-exits

resources:
  cloud: aws

setup: |
  echo "running setup"
  # python -c "raise RuntimeError('setup failed')"

run: |
  echo "started"
  python -c "raise RuntimeError('run failed')"
```

The following is an output example of setup failure:
```
Task from YAML spec: ./examples/minimal.yaml
Running task on cluster min...

I 02-24 01:19:15 optimizer.py:337] minimal  AWS(m4.2xlarge)I 02-24 01:19:15 optimizer.py:337] I 02-24 01:19:15 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1016] Creating a new cluster: "min" [1x AWS(m4.2xlarge)].

I 02-24 01:19:15 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:675] I 02-24 01:19:15 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:675] Launching on AWS us-east-1 (us-east-1a,us-east-1b,us-east-1c,us-east-1d,us-east-1e,us-east-1f)

title: Add document for `bash script.sh` cannot do `conda activate` problem
body:
`conda activate` will generate the following error in bash script, if not properly setup. #422 
```
CommandNotFoundError: Your shell has not been properly configured to use 'conda activate'.                                                   
To initialize your shell, run                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                             
    $ conda init <SHELL_NAME>                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                             
Currently supported shells are:                                                                                                              
  - bash                                                                                                                                     
  - fish                                                                                                                                     
  - tcsh                                                                                                                                     
  - xonsh                                                                                                                                    
  - zsh                                                                                                                                      
  - powershell                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                             
See 'conda init --help' for more information and options. 
```

By some experiments,  I found that adding`. $(conda info --base)/etc/profile.d/conda.sh 2> /dev/null || true` at the end of the `~/.bashrc` and let the user do `source ~/.bashrc` at the beginning of the `user_setup.sh` will not correctly enable `conda activate`. 

The only way that will work is to add the command `. $(conda info --base)/etc/profile.d/conda.sh` at the beginning of `user_setup.sh` or let the user call their script with `bash -i user_setup.sh`.

I decided to add a comment in quickstart to let the user call `bash -i` for their own script.

title: Revert to using file_mounts for object mounting
body:
Closes #409. Here's a summary:

1. With #324, we moved any file_mount of the form `/dst/: <cloudstore>://` to use `sky.Storage` behind the scenes. This was done with the eventual vision that cloud storage will support writes, and thus cloud paths should use cloud storage.

2. However, this broke syncing single objects (e.g. `  /train-00001-of-01024: gs://cloud-tpu-test-datasets/fake_imagenet/train-00001-of-01024`). This was raised in #409. 

3. Ideally, I still want to use `sky.Storage` for cloud paths in file_mounts. However, this edge case of mounting **objects** instead of **buckets** requires special handling. I don't think sky.Storage should be used for mounting single files since it breaks the semantics of sky.Storage. 

Decision: For now, we will stick to not using sky storage for cloud paths in file_mounts and instead copy them using gsutil/aws. We should discuss how cloud objects (files on buckets) should be treated differently from cloud object stores (buckets).

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c min examples/minimal.yaml`.
- [x] `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh` (modulo Azure bug #413)

title: Fix `check_local_gpus`
body:
Fixes #410 

Now the function additionally checks if the `nvidia-smi` toolkit actually works by seeing its return code.
If the machine has a GPU, `nvidia-smi` will return successfully.
Otherwise, `nvidia-smi` returns:
```bash
NVIDIA-SMI has failed because it couldn't communicate with the NVIDIA driver. Make sure that the latest NVIDIA driver is installed and running.
```
with the return code 9.

title: Decouple `ray up` and user's file_mounts / setup
body:
As mentioned in #400, our previous implementation has the user's file_mounts / setup coupled with the `ray up`. That makes it hard for us to have fine-grained control of them, make the cluster available as soon as it launched, and get rid of bugs of ray autoscalar. This PR aims to decouple them, implementing the proposal in #400.

title: Fixes for document and README
body:
I am adding more instructions during setting up a new machine (AWS VM with Deep Learning AMI) for sky using `pip install ".[all]"`, and fixing #355 Problem: - [x] Following the instruction of installing gcloud, `gcloud` is not found. It can be caused by the error below from `conda install -c conda-forge google-cloud-sdk` ``` Preparing transaction: done Verifying transaction: failed RemoveError: 'requests' is a dependency of conda and cannot be removed from conda's operating environment. ``` Fixed by `conda update --force conda`. - [x] `sky check` produces different instructions for GCP compare to our document. - [ ] `sky cpunode --cloud azure` does not work, raising the following error. @suquark Do you know what the problem is? The `sky check` shows azure is `enabled`. ``` azure.core.exceptions.ClientAuthenticationError: DefaultAzureCredential failed to retrieve a token from the included credentials. Attempted credentials: EnvironmentCredential: EnvironmentCredential authentication unavailable. Environment variables are not fully configured. Visit https://aka.ms/azsdk/python/identity/environmentcredential/troubleshoot to troubleshoot.this issue. ManagedIdentityCredential: Unexpected content type "text/html" Content: 404 - Not Found

404 - Not Found

``` Tested: - Following the installation page to set up the environment and able to launch cpunode on gcp/aws. Future TODOs: - The Azure-cli is problematic for dependencies. Installing azure-cli in base conda environment of the Deep Learning AMI (`ami-09ac68f361e5f4a13`) will cause `urllib3` version mismatch. The user has to create a new conda environment to solve that.

title: Add YAML configuration docs and fix CLI reference formatting
body:
Making sphinx and click behave nicely together is difficult!

## Completed
- [x] Add empty YAML check
- [x] Add "maximal.yaml" to docs
- [x] Fix formatting of CLI reference

## Before
![Screen Shot 2022-02-17 at 4 03 24 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2015126/154592194-89525510-8759-4f9d-9dbc-e4801f35d371.png)


## After
![Screen Shot 2022-02-17 at 4 03 59 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2015126/154592227-41d59c6e-9d4b-469e-a9ac-039190edc5e0.png)

```
sky ❯ tnode --help
Usage: sky tpunode [OPTIONS]

  Launch or attach to an interactive TPU node.

  Example:

      # Launch a default tpunode.
      sky tpunode

      # Do work, then log out. The node is kept running. Attach back to the
      # same node and do more work.
      sky tpunode

      # Create many interactive nodes by assigning names via --cluster (-c).
      sky tpunode -c node0
      sky tpunode -c node1

      # Port forward.
      sky tpunode --port-forward 8080 --port-forward 4650 -c cluster_name
      sky tpunode -p 8080 -p 4650 -c cluster_name

      # Sync current working directory to ~/workdir on the node.
      rsync -r . cluster_name:~/workdir

Options:
  -c, --cluster TEXT          A cluster name. If provided, either reuse an
                              existing cluster with that name or provision a
                              new cluster with that name. Otherwise provision
                              a new cluster with an autogenerated name.
  -p, --port-forward INTEGER  Port to be forwarded. To forward multiple ports,
                              use this option multiple times.
  -t, --instance-type TEXT    Instance type to use.
  --tpus TEXT                 Type and number of TPUs to use (e.g.,
                              --tpus=tpu-v3-8:4 or --tpus=tpu-v3-8).
  --spot                      If true, use spot instances.
  --screen                    If true, attach using screen.
  --tmux                      If true, attach using tmux.
  --help                      Show this message and exit.
```
